Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Deciphering the Mechanisms of Wear to Enable High Performance Tip-Based Nanomanufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tip-based nanomanufacturing (TBN) is a promising and scalable platform for fabricating nanostructures en masse with high precision. All TBN processes hinge on the availability of nanoscale atomic force microscope (AFM) tips that can survive the long-lasting and harsh conditions of TBN processes without substantial changes in composition or geometry. However, the scientific understanding of nanoscale wear, particularly under the extreme conditions encountered as TBN processes are scaled up, is lacking. This grant provides funding to rigorously develop the fundamental science of nanoscale wear that is needed to realize robust probes for high-performance, high-rate TBN processes. The integrated, interdisciplinary research plan consists of advanced atomistic simulations integrated with continuum models, and innovative experiments that include in-situ wear studies combining AFM with electron microscopy. The research will focus on understanding the performance of ultrananocrystalline diamond (UNCD) AFM probes manufactured by the industrial partner, Advanced Diamond Technologies (ADT), as well as conventional commercial probes based on silicon. Interactions with additional industrial collaborators pursuing commercial TBN processes will be leveraged to select relevant conditions for the studies, and to optimize the design of scalable TBN processes and probes based on the research findings.

If successful, this research will transform a broad range of TBN methods from bench-top prototype processes to commercially-viable applications. This will be achieved by realizing new approaches to minimize tip wear in scaled-up TBN processes. The understanding of wear that is developed will apply to the design and fabrication of reliable probes for a broad range of TBN methods. Tangible outcomes will include the deployment of UNCD probes for high performance TBN, and the establishment of operating conditions for achieving improved performance in commercially-viable TBN. The education and outreach activities will lead to a new short-course on TBN aimed at industry audiences, research experiences for high school science teachers, and the advanced training of students.

Institution.Name: University of Pennsylvania
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tip-based nanomanufacturing (TBN) is a promising new method for creating nanostructures with high precision. Applications for TBN include data storage, patterning for producing electronics, and fabricating small devices. All TBN processes hinge on the availability of using extremely small tips that do not change their size or shape due to wear, despite being subjected to harsh conditions for long periods of time during their use in TBN processes. Unfortunately, it is very difficult to control or predict wear because there is a lack of scientific understanding of the mechanisms that cause it. The intellectual merit of this work was to study and develop new fundamental scientific insights into the mechanisms underlying nanoscale wear. We used modern experimental and simulation tools to investigate what controls wear at the atomic scale, and did this in partnership with a company, Advanced Diamond Technologies (ADT), that produces probes for TBN applications. We showed that TBN probes developed with ADT made of diamond were more wear-resistant than standard existing probes made of silicon. We then showed that the processes leading to wear can be understood as chemical reactions that are altered by the local forces acting on the atoms involved in the reactions. We also studied how the wear processes depended on temperature, sliding speed, environment, and material. We developed ways to model and predict wear for several cases, producing experimental methods and models that others can use for further studies and predictions of wear. This broader technological impact of this project is that it provides researchers and industry with tools, methods, and practices to design wear-resistant probes for TBN, and also provides insights that can be used to understand how wear occurs in other applications. This is beneficial since reducing wear can enhance the lifetime of machines and devices, saving costs, enhancing safety, and reducing energy consumption. The broader educational impact of this work was to provide students and postdoctoral researchers with valuable training, and also involved participating in public science outreach events that educated the general public in the related topics of adhesion, friction, lubrication, and wear of materials. 

 


Last Modified: 01/26/2017
Modified by: Robert W Carpick
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Tip-based nanomanufacturing (TBN) is a promising new method for creating nanostructures with high precision. Applications for TBN include data storage, patterning for producing electronics, and fabricating small devices. All TBN processes hinge on the availability of using extremely small tips that do not change their size or shape due to wear, despite being subjected to harsh conditions for long periods of time during their use in TBN processes. The broader educational impact of this work was to provide students and postdoctoral researchers with valuable training, and also involved participating in public science outreach events that educated the general public in the related topics of adhesion, friction, lubrication, and wear of materials.
